rsbNotes.title: 1 Kings 20:1
rsbNotes.text:
20:1 Ben-hadad the king of Syria. This is probably Ben-hadad II, grandson of the Ben-hadad mentioned in 15:18–20.

Thirty-two kings. Ben-hadad II assembled a coalition of thirty-two kings of client city-states and tribal chieftains to campaign against Ahab.

rsbNotes.title: 1 Kings 20:4
rsbNotes.text: 20:4 my lord, O king. Ahab addresses Ben-hadad as an inferior to a superior. Ahab hoped that by surrendering he could preserve his own life and prevent his city from being destroyed.

rsbNotes.title: 1 Kings 20:9
rsbNotes.text: 20:9 this thing I cannot do. In his surrender (v. 4) Ahab did not contemplate actually handing over women and children, at least not those in his own palace and retinue.

rsbNotes.title: 1 Kings 20:10
rsbNotes.text: 20:10 The gods do so to me. Enraged at Ahab’s refusal, Ben-hadad promises to reduce Samaria to a heap of dust.

rsbNotes.title: 1 Kings 20:11
rsbNotes.text: 20:11 him who straps on his armor. Ahab responds with a proverb that it is foolish to boast about winning before the fight has begun.

rsbNotes.title: 1 Kings 20:13
rsbNotes.text: 20:13 I will give it into your hand this day. This is the form of assurance given before battles when the Lord is about to fight on Israel’s side (Josh. 6:2, 16; 8:1, 18; Judg. 7:2; 18:10; 2 Chr. 13:16; 16:8). God defends the cause of His people against oppressors and enemies (Ex. 15:1–21; Judg. 5; Hab. 3:3–19; Rev. 18).

rsbNotes.title: 1 Kings 20:16
rsbNotes.text: 20:16 drinking himself drunk. The thirty-two kings were over-confident and callous about their responsibilities.

rsbNotes.title: 1 Kings 20:23
rsbNotes.text:
20:23 Their gods are gods of the hills. Both Samaria and Jerusalem in the central hill country. In the polytheistic conceptions of the time, each god had specific zones of influence and strengths.

fight against them in the plain. It was understood that wars were fought not only by armies but also by their gods, and the Syrians wanted to fight in the plains where they thought Yahweh would be outside his sphere of influence and hence in a weak position.

rsbNotes.title: 1 Kings 20:24
rsbNotes.text: 20:24 remove the kings. The kings had been getting drunk (vv. 12, 16) and it would be wise to replace them with fighting men.

rsbNotes.title: 1 Kings 20:26
rsbNotes.text: 20:26 Aphek. About four miles east of the Sea of Chinneroth (Galilee).

rsbNotes.title: 1 Kings 20:31
rsbNotes.text:
20:31 the kings of . . . Israel are merciful. Certain powers in the Near East, such as Assyria, were brutal toward the vanquished.

sackcloth . . . ropes. The Syrians were dramatizing their humility and submission to the Israelites.

rsbNotes.title: 1 Kings 20:32
rsbNotes.text:
20:32 Your servant. Earlier, Ahab had addressed Ben-hadad as a superior (vv. 4, 9); now the tables are turned.

He is my brother. Ahab’s surprising response depicts Ben-hadad as an equal in a treaty relationship (9:13), a concession Ben-hadad’s men were quick to exploit (v. 33).

rsbNotes.title: 1 Kings 20:34
rsbNotes.text:
20:34 you may establish bazaars. International trade could bring substantial income (10:23–29), and the guarantee of a market in another country would afford a distinct economic advantage for the merchants of Israel.

these terms. The two kings formalize their negotiations by ratifying a covenant or treaty.

rsbNotes.title: 1 Kings 20:35
rsbNotes.text: 20:35 sons of the prophets. This designation does not mean physical children, but members of a prophetic guild or association. Elijah and Elisha were probably leaders of such groups (2 Kin. 2:3, 15; 4:1, 38; 6:1; 9:1).

rsbNotes.title: 1 Kings 20:36
rsbNotes.text:
20:36 Because you have not obeyed the . . . Lord. This highly unusual incident needs to be understood in the context of the previous story in which Ahab did not obey the dictates of holy war. Aware of Ahab’s treaty with Ben-hadad II, the prophet is dramatizing the consequences of refusing to heed the word of God.

a lion shall strike you. The old prophet from Bethel uttered a similar decree of judgment against the man of God from Judah (13:20–25).

rsbNotes.title: 1 Kings 20:39
rsbNotes.text: 20:39 a talent of silver. This was a huge quantity (about 75 pounds), more than a common soldier could afford.

rsbNotes.title: 1 Kings 20:40
rsbNotes.text: 20:40 So shall your judgment be. Ahab shows no mercy, and so passes judgment on himself (v. 42; 2 Sam. 12:7).

rsbNotes.title: 1 Kings 20:42
rsbNotes.text:
20:42 whom I had devoted to destruction. See Lev. 27:28; Josh. 6:17; 7:1, 20–26. The wars were campaigns fought and won by God Himself, using the Israelites as His agents. In fighting these wars Israel was to conduct itself in a prescribed manner, observing stipulations of holy conduct. Ahab was willing to accept divine victory, but he violated the rules for the holy war by making a treaty with Ben-hadad and yoking Israel to a foreign power (Deut. 7:1–6; 20:16–18).

your life shall be for his life, and your people for his people. Even though each person is responsible for his own conduct before God, the actions of each person inevitably affect the lives of others for good or ill.

rsbNotes.title: 1 Kings 21:1
rsbNotes.text: 21:1 Jezreel. About twenty-four miles north of Samaria. Ahab maintained a palace here in addition to one in the capital (18:45).

rsbNotes.title: 1 Kings 21:2
rsbNotes.text: 21:2 Give me your vineyard. In Canaanite nations a king could seize property and personal belongings at pleasure, because in theory all the property was owned by the royal family and only entrusted to their subjects. In Israel, God owned the land (Ex. 19:3–8; Lev. 25:23) and the people held it as His stewards (Num. 14:8; 35:34; Deut. 1:8). The powers of an Israelite monarch were limited in contrast to the powers of a Canaanite king (Deut. 17:14–20; 1 Sam. 8:9–19; 10:25). When Ahab wanted his neighbor’s vineyard, his thought was to negotiate a purchase (cf. 16:24).

rsbNotes.title: 1 Kings 21:3
rsbNotes.text: 21:3 The Lord forbid. Naboth’s reaction was quick, because his land was a sacred inheritance from the Lord. When the land was distributed following the conquest (Josh. 13–21), each family received its own inheritance as a divine gift and a trust. Since Naboth’s vineyard was his portion of his family’s inheritance, to sell it would mean cutting off his own descendants (Lev. 25:23; Num. 27:1–11; 36:1–12).

rsbNotes.title: 1 Kings 21:8
rsbNotes.text: 21:8 she wrote letters . . . to the elders and the leaders. Jezebel used the royal power to have Naboth falsely accused and executed.

rsbNotes.title: 1 Kings 21:9
rsbNotes.text: 21:9 Proclaim a fast. Jezebel, with Ahab’s complicity, fosters apprehensiveness among the town’s inhabitants, because fasting was a characteristic response to a crisis or major transgression (Judg. 20:26; 1 Sam. 7:5, 6; 2 Chr. 20:3; Jon. 3:5, 7–9).

rsbNotes.title: 1 Kings 21:10
rsbNotes.text:
21:10 two worthless men. The law of Israel stipulated that at least two witnesses were required to convict a person of a capital offense (Num. 35:30; Deut. 17:5, 6; 19:15).

cursed God and the king. The penalty for cursing God was death (Ex. 22:28; Lev. 24:10–16).

rsbNotes.title: 1 Kings 21:13
rsbNotes.text: 21:13 outside the city. In accordance with the Law, the murderers avoided ritual impurity (Lev. 24:14; Num. 15:35, 36). Second Kings 9:26 adds that Naboth’s sons were also killed, eliminating any possible heirs.

rsbNotes.title: 1 Kings 21:24
rsbNotes.text: 21:24 dogs . . . birds of the heavens shall eat. See 14:11 and note.

rsbNotes.title: 1 Kings 21:25
rsbNotes.text: 21:25 There was none . . . like Ahab. See 16:30–33 and notes.

rsbNotes.title: 1 Kings 21:26
rsbNotes.text: 21:26 Amorites. The word here refers to the pre-Israelite inhabitants of Canaan (Gen. 15:16; Deut. 1:7; 2 Sam. 21:2).

rsbNotes.title: 1 Kings 21:27
rsbNotes.text: 21:27 tore his clothes and put sackcloth on. God’s judgment, uttered through Elijah, changes Ahab’s attitude. Tearing clothes and wearing sackcloth were marks of mourning and repentance (Gen. 37:34; 2 Sam. 3:31; 2 Kin. 6:30; Lam. 2:10; Joel 1:13).

rsbNotes.title: 1 Kings 21:29
rsbNotes.text:
21:29 I will not bring the disaster in his days. God revises the punishment He gave in vv. 21–24. The penalty was not rescinded but delayed a generation due to God’s mercy.

his son’s days. That is, Joram (2 Kin. 9:25, 26). Though Ahab would not live to see the end of his dynasty, he and Jezebel died shameful deaths (22:37, 38; 2 Kin. 9:10, 34–37).
